texts.definition: Outcomes of player actions that depends both on both player and character characteristics.
markups: <style="Definition">Outcomes of player actions that depends both on both player and character characteristics.</style>

Many games make the outcome of actions depend on player skills, but other games make use of the skills and equipment used by the diegetic characters. When games make use of both simultaneously, so both player and character characteristics are merged to form a synthesized skill, the outcome of actions become dependent on <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> for two reasons. First, although players may choose the actions performed by the characters, it is their skills, levels, and equipment that determine the outcome (at least for rule-based versions of this type of games). Second, game masters often provide bonuses (or penalties) depending on how well players planned, described, and enacted the characters' actions. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roguelikes">Roguelike</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unexplored">Unexplored</link></style> works similarly but as a real-time <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Game</link></style> also puts demands on players manual dexterity and reflexes.

While all <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style> (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%20series">Half-Life series</link></style>) that have different types of weapons have a certain level of <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> some games make more explicit use of the pattern. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%202">Left 4 Dead 2</link></style> lets players find laser sights that upgrade weapons so that they sway less when one aims. This makes shooting a combination of player skill and character equipment. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Borderlands">Borderlands</link></style> allows many different upgrades of weapons and lowers the sway of weapons for skilled characters (the "Aim Assist" option in the game can be seen as a version of the pattern as well).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Zero-Player%20Games">Zero-Player Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/C-Robots">C-Robots</link></style> have a form of <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> in that outcomes depend on players' skill in programming the robots that then perform them. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> has a limited form of this in that both players' characters and companions can be given tactics, simple rules for how to behave in combat.

Creating <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> consists of designing the outcomes of actions so that they depend both on how (and when) players perform actions and on attributes tied to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Examples of ways players can show personal skills or competences include performing <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>. Examples of how <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can affect outcomes of actions are by having <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> related to the actions, and by providing <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style> augmented with <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> let perception of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> be a composite of players and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> abilities. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> are ways to more directly tie <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> to the actual performing of the actions, and <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style> (or games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> that allow players to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> over <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style>) make players into the creators of <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> that provide <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>. Setting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> can allow a lesser form of <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> to exist when players can influence <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> behaviors (done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> and more weakly in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>). The pattern can be used when no abstract features of players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> exist except <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, i.e. the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> pattern is not used, but is then rather a way to modulate <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. In general, <style="Link"><link="player-augmentations">Player Augmentations</link></style> can be used to create <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> in all cases where the augmentation can be traced to the diegetic representation of a character.

<style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> is an activity that quite often depends on <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style>. One example is making hitting depend on player skill while <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> depends on character <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>. The difficulty of performing <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions can more tightly merge the two components through having player do the aiming but let the sway of the aim depend on <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> and their <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style>, as well as on <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> to produce <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>. All these options can also be used to initiate or influence <style="Link"><link="auto-aim">Auto-Aim</link></style> functionality and thereby create <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> have to balance the <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> if any of the two are to exist in a game. Those where <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> over time influences outcomes more than <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> lessen the <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> for the <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>; this may however be compensated by the <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> having the mastery represents. It may however also make <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> difficult to achieve without other <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>. Dominating influence from <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> can directly work against <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> occurring (see Linderoth 2010<ref name="linderoth"/> for a discussion related to this), and even if <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> occurs <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> works against its <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>. Note that this is not the same type of balance that needs to be maintained between difficulty and chance to succeed to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> is an alternative way of achieving <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> since actions, and even the performance of them, can be attributes of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but players decide when they are done. Likewise, the presence of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can allow <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> by letting <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> beyond that possible from the game state modify the chance of success for any action.

<style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> are likely to be affected by <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> in games that contain them, so the co-presence of these pattern should be considered in any game design process using one or the other.

In games where players control <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that are supposed to be skilled, <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> can help maintain <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> until the players have gain enough <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> to be able to enact these levels of skill.

Per its definition, <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style> combines the attributes of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and skill of players to determine outcomes of actions. This can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> initially since the outcome from novices may not be that of diegetic novices. When the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> part actively performs actions, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, this makes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player/System%20Action%20Composites">Player/System Action Composites</link></style> emerge and naturally affect <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> is typically lessened by the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Player/Character Skill Composites</style>.

The pattern may also give rise to <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style> since players can compensate a lack of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> by playing more to have <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> or better <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> instead.
